class_notes:
(Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only)


Jean-Baptiste Poquelin, aka Molière, was born January 15, 1622, 400 years ago.  Molière was an actor and playwright who transformed the French theatre by borrowing concepts from Italian, commedia dell'arte troupes and breaking down neo-classical genre boundaries.  Molière wrote serious comedies, sometimes in verse, comedy ballets, and short farces. Many of these works seem strangely relevant to our own age despite the four centuries that have passed.
This class explores the life and craft of Molière. We will read five of Molière's plays and some work that influenced him. We will read some scenarios of the Italian Comedy that influenced his style and also examine the music of composers Lully and Charpentier who collaborated with Molière, Tirso de Molina who influenced him and Mozart who adapted Don Juan into the opera Don Giovanni. 
Plays we will all read will include: The Flying Doctor, Sganarelle or The Imaginary Cuckold, The Bourgeois Gentleman, School for Wives, Tartuffe, and Don Juan.
We will watch the operas Don Giovanni (available through the Emory Library Met on Demand collection) and Molière & Lully's Bourgeois Gentleman (available through Emory Library's medici.tv collection)
